intro: Grumilea radicans, commonly known as the trailing grumihedra, is a climbing plant native to tropical regions of South America. It features heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a soft, velvety texture. The plant produces small, fragrant flowers in clusters, typically in shades of white and pink. Its stems are flexible and can trail along the ground or climb supports, making it suitable for hanging baskets or trellises. Botanically, it belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes other flowering plants with similar structural and floral characteristics.
